entry.title: Pashinyan heads to Moscow despite strained Russia ties

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan heads to Moscow despite strained Russia ties
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenian Prime Minister Pashinyan will attend Moscow‚Äôs Victory Day celebrations tomorrow amid strained ties with Russia. üìç Armenia voiced strong support for India‚Äôs right to self-defense after recent anti-terror strikes in Pakistan, while Azerbaijan supports Pakistan. üìç Truckloads of Armenian alcohol shipments are stalled at the Georgia-Russia border due to unexpected Georgian customs tests, causing major delays and financial losses for exporters. üìç Armenia‚Äôs government will expand drainage system upgrades in Yerevan and other cities after severe flooding, aiming for long-term infrastructure solutions starting next year.

entry.title: What would it take to defeat Pashinyan?

media:group.media:title: What would it take to defeat Pashinyan?
media:group.media:description:
In this episode of the CivilNet podcast, commentator Eric Hacopian surveys the political field ahead of the 2026 Armenian parliamentary elections, which will pit Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan against known and possibly yet-to-emerge opposition figures. He discusses the impact that a referendum to change the country‚Äôs constitution will have on Pashinyan‚Äôs prospects, as well as what it will take for each side to win. He also considers the matters of foreign interference and possible events that could drastically alter the situation.

entry.title: Former presidents argue over tactics to topple Pashinyan

media:group.media:title: Former presidents argue over tactics to topple Pashinyan
media:group.media:description:
üìç Tensions among Armenia‚Äôs opposition forces deepened as former President Robert Kocharyan‚Äôs Armenia Alliance accused Serzh Sargsyan‚Äôs We Are Awake movement of attempting to blackmail its MPs amid efforts to initiate a motion of no confidence against Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan. üìç The Armenian Patriarchate of Jerusalem strongly condemned the head of the Russian Orthodox Church for honoring Azerbaijani First Lady Mehriban Aliyeva during a visit to Baku. üìç Yerevan Mayor Tigran Avinyan‚Äôs lawyer claimed in court his client‚Äôs harsh remarks did not target CivilNet. The mayor is being sued over offensive language he used during a televised debate, targeting CivilNet‚Äôs investigation of financial corruption related to Avinyan and his family. üìç Armenia‚Äôs labor rights challenges: https://www.civilnet.am/en/news/948963/informal-employment-low-awareness-hinder-labor-rights-in-armenia/
